cards.calloutText: Also: We have formally submitted our comment in support of the DOT's new proposed Airline Ticket Refunds and Consumer Protections rule. Click here to see the submission that is accompanied by thousands of signatures from our readers, like you. Thank you to those of you that joined in this action, and to all of you who shared our reporting about the airline regulation debacle under Secretary Buttigieg. The effects of this work are being felt far and wide.

sections: ‚Äôs podcasts covered a lot of ground. On

, I spoke with journalist Moe Tkacik and Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser about the potential merger between grocery store giants Kroger and Albertsons. It‚Äôs an important story that hasn‚Äôt gotten much attention in corporate media, so I was eager to learn about how detrimental this new grocery monopoly could be for consumers and the companies‚Äô employees.

, the study group FINALLY completes David Axelrod and Karl Rove‚Äôs MasterClass on campaign strategy. If you ever believed the myth that Democrats are somehow ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than Republicans, watching Axelrod act chummy with Rove (one of the most repugnant political strategists in modern history) will almost certainly set you straight.

‚Äôs study group provides decades‚Äô worth of political history to help contextualize the legacies of these two Washington con men. You‚Äôll learn, you‚Äôll laugh, you‚Äôll cry, and you‚Äôll definitely walk away disliking these guys more than you did before.
Learn more and find the episode links below.
The Corporate Merger No One‚Äôs Talking About

Last October, grocery giants Kroger and Albertsons announced they planned to merge and become one of the largest grocery monopolies in the country. To learn what‚Äôs at stake, David Sirota is joined by journalist Moe Tkacik, who has been covering the story for months, and Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser, who recently launched a multistate antitrust investigation into the potential merger.

Producer Frank, Andrew Perez, and Julia Rock discuss the ‚ÄúOne Thing‚Äù that‚Äôs been most on their mind recently. This week, they discuss the potential UPS strike, how to hold a ‚Äúliberal intervention,‚Äù and Larry Summers‚Äô call for more unemployment while literally on vacation.
In the new episode of our ‚Äúeducational‚Äù series

, Dave, Josh, and their study buddy Senator Nina Turner audit the final lessons of David Axelrod and Karl Rove‚Äôs 24-part MasterClass on campaign strategy and messaging. Did they learn anything valuable? Absolutely not. Did they have a great time cutting through Axelrod and Rove‚Äôs whitewashed propaganda? Well, that‚Äôs a more subjective question.

During the final lessons, Axelrod and Rove discuss the current state of American politics, and the study group breaks down their discussion in real time. You might be surprised to learn which of these two campaign pros actually understands why our politics have become so divisive and which one is completely oblivious to any measurable reality. Actually, you probably won't be.
